title: Towards Theoretically Understanding Why Sgd Generalizes Better Than Adam in Deep Learning

From Sec.Â 3.1, we can formulate SgdÂ as follows To analyze behaviors of an algorithm, one effective approach is to obtain its SDE via making assumptions on ğ’–tsubscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ m{u}_{t} and then analyze its SDE. For instance, to analyze Sgd, most worksÂ [ref]25  [ref]26  assume that ğ’–tsubscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ m{u}_{t} obeys a Gaussian distribution ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğšºt)ğ’©0subscriptğšºğ‘¡\mathcal{N}( m{0},\! m{\Sigma}_{t}) with covariance matrix However, both recent workÂ  and Fig.Â 1 show that the gradient noise ğ’–tsubscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ m{u}_{t} has heavy tails and can be better characterized by ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S} distributionÂ . Moreover, the heavy-tail assumption can also better explain the behaviors of SgdÂ than Gaussian noise assumption. Concretely, for the SDE of SgdÂ on the one-dimensional problems, under Gaussian noise assumption its escaping time from a simple quadratic basin respectively exponentially and polynomially depends on the height and width of the basinÂ , indicating that SgdÂ gets stuck at deeper minima as opposed to wider/flatter minima. This contradicts with the observations inÂ  9   that SgdÂ often converges to flat minima. By contrast, on the same problem, for LÃ©vy-driven SDE, both  and this work show that SgdÂ tends to converge to flat minima instead of deep minima, well explaining the convergence behaviors of Sgd. FollowingÂ , we also assume ğ’–tsubscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ m{u}_{t} obeys ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S} distribution but with a time-dependent covariance matrix ğšºtsubscriptğšºğ‘¡ m{\Sigma}_{t} to better characterize the underlying structure in the gradient noise ğ’–tsubscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ m{u}_{t}. Intuitively, the ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S} distribution is a heavy-tailed distribution with a decay density like 1/|x|1+Î±1superscriptğ‘¥1ğ›¼1/|x|^{1+\alpha}. When the tail index Î±ğ›¼\alpha is 2, ğ’®â€‹Î±â€‹ğ’®â€‹(1)ğ’®ğ›¼ğ’®1\mathcal{S}\alpha\mathcal{S}(1) becomes a Gaussian distribution and thus has stronger data-fitting capacity over Gaussian distribution. In this sense, the SDE of SgdÂ inÂ [ref]25  [ref]26   is actually a special case of the LÃ©vy-driven SDE in this work. Moreover, Eqn.Â (4) extends the one-dimensional SDE of SgdÂ inÂ . Note, Eqn.Â (4) differs from [ref]29, since it considers dynamic covariance matrix ğšºtsubscriptğšºğ‘¡ m{\Sigma}_{t} in gradient noise and shows great effects of its underlying structure to the escaping behaviors in both AdamÂ andÂ Sgd, while [ref]29 analyzed escaping behaviors of SgdÂ along several fixed directions. Similarly, we can derive the SDE of Adam.
